title: How to Regrow Pineapples

steps.headline: Obtain a pineapple.
steps.description: You can get one at a store that sells pineapples and it doesn't necessarily need to be organic

steps.headline: Twist the green stem and leaves of the pineapple.
steps.description: Try to avoid pulling off any of the leaves or damaging the stem in any way.

steps.headline: Remove some of the bottom leaves.
steps.description: It should be one to two rows of the bottom leaves near the stem bottom. Pull them off nicely and discard them.

steps.headline: Fill a designated container big enough for the pineapple to fit with water.
steps.description: One or two inches is perfect.

steps.headline: Place the pineapple in the container.
steps.description: Make sure the water isn't submerging any of the leaves. In 1-5 days, the pineapple stem should grow roots.

steps.headline: Keep the water clean by replacing it with fresh water every few days.
steps.description: Do not touch the roots, as you could damage them or make them fall off.

steps.headline: The leaves should continue to grow.
steps.description: If some/most of the leaves on the stem turn brown, cut them off (this doesn't hurt the plant as long as you don't cut the green part of the leaves. It also helps prevent mold)

steps.headline: When the roots are strong and healthy, the leaves are green and thriving.
steps.description: Prepare to plant the pineapple. Don't rush the pineapple; give it at least a few weeks before planting.

steps.headline: Fill a pot/container with soil, preferably a type that is well suited for growing fruits
Dig a hole in the center of the pot/container/ground and place the pineapple in the hole
steps.description: Make sure the soil doesn't cover green leaves Bury the browning/dying leaves under the soil or remove them before planting

steps.headline: Make sure to water your pineapple plant daily.
steps.description: You should aim for one or two cups of water, or more depending where you live and whether your plant is indoor or outdoors

steps.headline: The pineapple plant may produce fruit in one to three years.
steps.description: This usually depends on the plant, so fruiting cycles may vary.

steps.headline: Harvest the fruit by cutting/twisting from the stem that connects it to the plant.
steps.description: Remember to only harvest the fruit when it's big enough to eat.
